column8: Central to western N. America - Manitoba and Minnesota south to Arizona.
column13: Fully Hardy,Well drained soil,Moist Soil,Full sun
column16: Helianthus petiolaris is a ANNUAL growing to 3 m (9ft 10in).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 4.  It is in flower from July to September. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Bees, flies.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils and prefers  well-drained soil. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It cannot grow in the shade. It prefers dry or  moist soil.
column19: Seed: includes nuts, cereals, peas and beans.
column21: Seed - raw or cooked. An oily texture[161, 177]. The seed can be ground into a powder and kneaded into seed butter[257].
column22: Salve: Soothes and heals damaged skin.
column23: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.SalveThe powdered leaves, either on their own or in an ointment, have been used as a dressing for sores and swellings[257].
column27: Succeeds in most soils in a sunny position[1]. Requires a rich soil[1]. Dislikes shade[1]. Grows well on dry soils[200]. The young growth is extremely attractive to slugs, plants can be totally destroyed by them[K]. This species hybridizes in the wild with H. annuus[274]. Members of this genus are rarely if ever troubled by browsing deer or rabbits[233].
column28: Seed - sow in mid spring in situ. An earlier start can be made by sowing 2 - 3 seeds per pot in a greenhouse in early spring. Use a fairly rich compost. Thin to the strongest seedling, give them an occasional liquid feed to make sure they do not become nutrient deficient and plant them out in late spring or early summer.
